title: 111_s2780
content: The Act titled "Small Business Intermediary Lending Pilot Program Act of 2009" establishes the Small Business Intermediary Lending Pilot Program. The Small Business Act is amended to include the Small Business Intermediary Lending Pilot Program, defining an eligible intermediary as a private, nonprofit entity with experience in making loans to small businesses. The Small Business Intermediary Lending Pilot Program includes private, nonprofit community development corporations, consortiums of nonprofit organizations, and agencies established by Native American Tribal Governments. The Program is a 3-year pilot program where the Administrator can provide direct loans to eligible intermediaries. The Administrator can provide direct loans to eligible intermediaries for the purpose of lending to small businesses in areas with poor credit access. Loans can be used for working capital, real estate, or acquiring materials and equipment. Loans to eligible intermediaries require submission of an application describing small business concerns to be assisted, loan size and terms, geographic area served, and credit availability analysis. Loans made by the Administrator to eligible intermediaries under this subsection have a loan limit of $3,000,000, a duration of 20 years, and an annual interest rate of 1.00 percent. The Program offers loans to eligible intermediaries with an annual interest rate of 1.00 percent. No fees or collateral are required for these loans. Repayment of principal and interest is not required for the first 2 years. The Administrator may make loans to a maximum of 20 intermediaries each fiscal year. The Administrator offers loans to intermediaries with a maximum amount of $60,000,000. Loans are provided to small businesses for various purposes with a maximum loan amount of $200,000 per business. Interest rates on these loans can be fixed or variable. The Administrator offers loans to intermediaries with a maximum amount of $60,000,000 for small businesses. Loans may have fixed or variable interest rates specified by the intermediary. The Administrator's authority to make loans under the Program will end 3 years after the enactment of the Small Business Intermediary Lending Pilot Program Act of 2009. The Administrator will issue regulations within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Administrator will issue regulations for section 7(l) of the Small Business Act, with funds remaining available until expended.
